dt: {bc}to block off or stop up with a barricade
{bc}to prevent access to by means of a barricade

et: borrowed from Middle French, noun derivative of {it}barricade{/it} {et_link|barricade:2|barricade:2}
shortdef: to block off or stop up with a barricade
to prevent access to by means of a barricade

dt: {bc}an obstruction or rampart thrown up across a way or passage to check the advance of the enemy

et: borrowed from French, going back to Middle French, from {it}barrique{/it} "barrel," a typical component of barricades (borrowed from Gascon {it}barriqua{/it}, probably going back to pre-Latin {it}*barrīca{/it}) + {it}-ade{/it} {et_link|-ade|-ade}
shortdef: an obstruction or rampart thrown up across a way or passage to check the advance of the enemy

dt: {bc}to block oneself off from other people usually inside something as by locking doors or erecting barricades

dt.t: Students {it}barricaded themselves{/it} in the cafeteria to protest university policies.

shortdef: to block oneself off from other people usually inside something as by locking doors or erecting barricades
